(3) Develop green gases: biomethane (4 TWh in France by 2030; €800m 2018-2023 rising to €2bn by 2030; +700 GWh in France by 2023) and renewable hydrogen (4 GW electrolysers, 700 km network, 1 TWh storage, integrate 30 TWh hydrogen, >100 refueling stations by 2030). (4) Support customer decarbonization with a 2030 target of 45 mt CO2 eq avoided via ENGIE products/services and a methodology developed with external partners. (5) Reduce workplace/working-method emissions with Net Zero by 2030, including >35% building electricity reduction and >100% green vehicle fleet share by 2030. (6) Biodiversity action framework with 'avoid, reduce, offset' requirements for projects (2022/2025) and ecological management/environmental plans for sites/activities by 2030.

Execution is supported by CO2 management tools: CO2 Medium-Term Plan with annual CO2 budgets by business line through 2030, quarterly business reviews tracking emissions, CO2 flexibility tracking for investments/contracts, and internal carbon pricing in project valuation.

Products: pursue 10X client/server microprocessor energy efficiency by 2030 (2019 baseline) and reduce platform reference design carbon footprint ≥30% by 2030. Water and waste: target net positive water by 2030 (conserve 60B gallons cumulatively from 2020 and fund restoration projects) and zero waste to landfill by 2030 (<1%) with circular economy strategies for ≥60% of manufacturing waste streams.

years.action_plans:
Aim 1 (Scopes 1–2): implement operational efficiency (energy efficiency, electrification), reduce flaring/venting, and manage methane; use lower-carbon power agreements for refineries and onshore upstream assets; pursue CCS and hydrogen where suitable; continue identifying and progressing projects including flaring/venting reduction, energy efficiency, electrification and CCS.
Aim 2 (Scope 3 production emissions): reduce emissions largely through portfolio optimization and reducing oil and gas production (~25% lower by 2030 vs 2019 excluding Rosneft); consider future mitigation such as CCS for blue hydrogen or electricity.
Aim 3 (sold energy carbon intensity): grow bioenergy (biofuels to ~100 kb/d by 2030), expand EV charging (>100,000 charge points by 2030; energy sales >100-fold from 2021 to 2030), grow renewables & power and trading, and scale hydrogen (0.5–0.7 Mtpa by 2030).
Aim 4 (methane): deploy enhanced methane measurement and related technologies across major processing sites by end-2023, publish data, then drive 50% methane-intensity reduction against a new baseline; influence joint ventures to set methane-intensity targets of 0.2%; progress towards zero routine flaring by 2030 (2025 for bpx).
Aim 5 (transition investment): increase annual transition growth investment to $6–8bn by 2025 and $7–9bn by 2030 and increase capex share to >40% by 2025 and ~50% by 2030; execute through growth engines (bioenergy, convenience, EV charging, renewables & power, hydrogen) and strategic partnerships and acquisitions (e.g., Archaea Energy, EDF Energy Services).

years.action_plans:
Aim 1: reduce operational Scope 1+2 via energy efficiency measures, electrifying centralized facilities, reducing flaring/venting, process optimization and steam heat recovery; use lower-carbon power for refineries and onshore upstream assets; consider CCS/reinjection (e.g., Tangguh Enhanced Gas Recovery and CCS) and increased blue/green hydrogen at refineries; and portfolio optimization/high-grading.
Aim 4: implement methane measurement across upstream oil and gas assets (flare-efficiency software, predictive monitoring on gas turbines, updated meters), use drones/aircraft sensors for verification with wider deployment planned up to 2025; deploy Flare.IQ for near real-time flare performance; continue methane reduction projects (e.g., nitrogen purge gas) and lower-methane facility designs/centralized electrified facilities.
Aim 3 & 5: grow low carbon businesses and shift sold product mix (EV charging expansion including Tesla agreement and Iberdrola JV; bioenergy growth including Archaea Energy RNG growth; renewables and offshore wind growth; hydrogen initiatives including Advanced Ionics investment and HyVal cluster planning). Aim 10: develop integrated energy hubs and CCUS/hydrogen projects (e.g., Teesside) and support hard-to-abate sectors with electrification, hydrogen and biofuels.
